name: AIDA-X
label: AIDA-X
comment:
AIDA-X is an Amp Model Player, allowing it to load models of AI trained music gear, which you can then play through!

Its main intended use is to provide high fidelity simulations of amplifiers.
However, it is also possible to run entire signal chains consisting of any combination of amp, cab, dist, drive, fuzz, boost and eq.

name: Kars
label: Kars
comment: Simple karplus-strong plucked string synth.

name: MVerb
label: MVerb
comment: Studio quality reverb, provides a practical demonstration of Dattorro’s figure-of-eight reverb structure.

name: Nekobi
label: Nekobi
comment:
The Nekobi generator is based on the legendary Roland TB-303© (*).
This polemic bass-synthesizer got quite some critiques in its early days. Soon the public realised its incredible fit to trance, house and EDM music like no other device at the time. Loyal to its inspiration, the Nekobi is a monophonic synthesizer, which means only one note can be played at a time.

Features:
Modeled by FalkTX & Sean Bolton

(*) “Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
The Roland TB-303© is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”

name: Ping Pong Pan
label: Ping Pong Pan
comment:
The Ping Pong Pan fades the sound from left to right. 
It features 2 knobs. ‘Frequency’ controls how fast the directional change happens and ‘Width’ tells the amount of signal that gets faded. When the knob is set to 100%, audio on the left is muted when audio on the right is at full volume.

Features:
Modeled by FalkTX

name: Auto-wah
label: Wah
comment:
The auto-wah is a combination of an envelope follower and a resonant low pass filter.
For increasing sound levels, both the frequency and the bandwidth of the filter will increase. The intensity is controlled by 'Drive'.
For a normal wah, use an expression pedal to control 'Frequency' and set 'Drive' to zero.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP

name: CS Chorus 1
label: CS Chorus 1
comment:
Fomp is an LV2 port of the MCP, VCO, FIL, and WAH plugins by Fons Adriaensen.

Based on a CSound orchestra file by Sean Costello. There are two low frequency oscillators, each having three outputs that are 120 degrees apart in phase. The summed outputs modulate three delay lines.
Make sure the static delay (first parameter) is at least equal to the sum of the two modulation depths.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP

name: CS Chorus 2
label: CS Chorus 2
comment:
Fomp is an LV2 port of the MCP, VCO, FIL, and WAH plugins by Fons Adriaensen.

Functionally identical to variant 1, but upsamples the input to the delay lines in an attempt to mitigate the errors produced by the linear interpolation at the output.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP

name: CS Phaser 1 with LFO
label: CS Phaser 1+LFO
comment:
Fomp is an LV2 port of the MCP, VCO, FIL, and WAH plugins by Fons Adriaensen.

Similar to CS Phaser 1, but the external modulation has been replaced by a built-in LFO.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP

name: reverb
label: Reverb
comment:
Fomp is an LV2 port of the MCP, VCO, FIL, and WAH plugins by Fons Adriaensen.
This is a stereo reverb plugin based on the well-known G Reverb. One might think that this reverb was designed for the guitar - but it does wonders used on vocals.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP

name: Triple chorus
label: Triple Chorus
comment:
A Chorus effect with three separate outputs. Pan L, C and R for a nice stereo effect.

Features:
Modeled by FOMP

name: setBfree DSP Tonewheel Organ
label: setBfree
comment: setBfree is a MIDI-controlled, software synthesizer designed to imitate the sound and properties of the electromechanical organs and sound modification devices that brought world-wide fame to the names and products of Laurens Hammond and Don Leslie.

name: setBfree Whirl Speaker
label: Whirl Speaker
comment:
A rotating loudspeaker emulator designed to imitate the sound of device that brought world-wide fame to the name of Don Leslie.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: Autotune
label: Autotune
comment:
The AT1 is used to correct pitch within the vocal range and features a few different modes. The first one is the Auto mode - with this mode, the pitch will automatically be bent to the nearest true exact semitone. When selecting the MIDI mode, the pitch will be bent to the incoming midi note. The last mode is the manual mode, in which the keyboard on the pedalboard can be used.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: x42-eq - Parametric Equalizer Mono
label: Parametric EQ
comment:
A very complete EQ with visual response.
Featuring 4 bands, highpass and lowpass filters, you can now use your stomp box in order to tweak each edge of your sound as you like it.

Features:
Modeled by Robin Gareus

name: x42-eq - Parametric Equalizer Stereo
label: Parametric EQ ST
comment:
A very complete stereo EQ with visual response.
Featuring 4 bands, highpass and lowpass filters, you can now use your stomp box in order to tweak each edge of your sound as you like it.

Features:
Modeled by Robin Gareus

name: MIDI Clock Generator
label: MIDI Clock
comment:
A MIDI clock generator with optional host transport synchronization.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI CC to Note
label: MIDI CC to Note
comment:
MIDI CC to Note enables you to convert MIDI control change messages to note-on/off messages. Note off is queued 10 msec later.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Channel Filter
label: MIDI Chn Filter
comment:
MIDI channel filter. Only data for selected channel shall pass. This filter only affects midi-data which is channel relevant (ie note-on/off, control and program changes, key and channel pressure and pitch bend). MIDI-SYSEX and Realtime message are always passed on.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Channel Map
label: MIDI Chn Map
comment:
MIDI Channel Map enables you to rewrite midi-channel numbers. This filter only affects midi-data which is channel relevant (ie note-on/off, control and program changes, key and channel pressure and pitch bend). MIDI-SYSEX and Realtime message are always passed thru unmodified.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Enforce Scale
label: MIDI Force Scale
comment:
MIDI Enforce Scale enables you to filter note-on/off events depending on musical scale. If the key is changed note-off events of are sent for all active off-key notes.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Event Filter
label: MIDI Event Flt.
comment:
MIDI Event Filter is a notch style message filter. It enables you to suppress specific messages. For flexible note-on/off range see also 'keyrange' and 'velocityrange'.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Key-Range Filter
label: MIDI Key/Range
comment:
MIDI Key Range Filter lets you define a range of allowed midi notes. Notes-on/off events outside the allowed range are discarded. If the range changes, note-off events are sent to currently active notes that end up outside the valid range.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Keysplit
label: MIDI Keysplit
comment:
MIDI Keysplit enables you to change midi-channel number depending on note. The plugin keeps track of transposed midi-notes and sends note-off events accordingly if the range is changed even if a note is active.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI CC Map
label: MIDI CC Map
comment:
MIDI CC Map enables you to change one control message into another. Combined with MIDI Scale CC Value, it allows you to modify/scale the actual value.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Note/Channel Map
label: MIDI Key/Chn Map
comment:
A 12-tone channel map which allows you to change midi-channel per note.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Note Transpose
label: MIDI Note Transp
comment:
MIDI Note Transpose is a flexible 12-tone map which allows you to map a note within an octave to another note in the same octave-range +- 12 semitones. Alternatively, notes can also be disabled. The settings can be changed dynamically: Note-on/off events will be sent accordingly.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Chord
label: MIDI Chord
comment:
This harmonizer creates chords from a single (fundamental) note in a given musical scale. The scale as well as intervals can be automated freely (currently held chords will change). Note-ons are latched, for multiple/combined chords only single note-on/off will be triggered for the duration of the combined chords. If a off-scale note is given, it will be passed through - no chord is allocated.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Delayline
label: MIDI Delayline
comment:
MIDI Delayline enables you to delay all MIDI events by a given time which is shown as BPM and beats. If the delay includes a random factor, this effect takes care of always keeping note on/off events sequential regardless of the randomization.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Channel Unisono
label: MIDI Chn Unisono
comment:
MIDI Channel Filter Unisono enables you to duplicate MIDI events from one channel to another.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Strum
label: MIDI Strum
comment:
A midi arpeggio effect intended to simulate strumming a stringed instrument (e.g. guitar). A chord is 'collected' and the single notes of the chord are played back, spread out over time. The 'Note Collect Timeout' allows for the effect to be played live with midi-keyboard.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Chromatic Transpose
label: MIDI Transpose
comment:
A chromatic transpose of midi notes and key-pressure. If an inversion point is set, the scale is mirrored around this point before transposing. Notes that end up outside the valid range 0..127 are discarded.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Monophonic Legato
label: MIDI Mono Legato
comment:
MIDI Monophonic Legato allows you to hold a note until the next one arrives. In order to switch it off, replay the same note again.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Remove Active Sensing
label: MIDI No Act Sens
comment:
A filter made to block all active sensing events. Active sensing messages are optional MIDI messages intended to be sent repeatedly to tell a receiver that a connection is alive, however they can clutter up the MIDI channel or be inadvertently recorded when dumping raw MIDI data to disk.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Duplicate Blocker
label: MIDI Dup. Block
comment:
MIDI Duplicate Blocker enables you to filter out overlapping notes on/off and duplicate messages.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Note to CC
label: MIDI Note to CC
comment:
MIDI Note to CC allows you to convert only MIDI note-on messages to control change messages (ignored in toggle mode).

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Note Toggle
label: MIDI Note Toggle
comment:
With MIDI Note Toggle, play a note to turn it on and play it again to turn it off.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI N-Tap Delay
label: MIDI N-Tap Delay
comment:
MIDI N-Tap Delay repeats notes N times, where N is either a fixed number or unlimited as long as a given key is pressed. BPM and delay-time variable allows tempo-ramps. On every repeat the given velocity-adjustment is added or subtracted, the result is clamped between 1 and 127.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Simple Channel Filter
label: MIDI 1 Chn Flt.
comment:
Simple MIDI channel filter. Only data for selected channels may pass. This filter only affects midi-data which is channel relevant (ie note-on/off, control and program changes, key and channel pressure and pitchbend). MIDI-SYSEX and Realtime message are always passed on. See also 'MIDI Channel Map' filter.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Quantization
label: MIDI Quantize
comment:
Live event quantization. This filter aligns incoming MIDI events to a fixed time-grid. Since the effect operates on a live-stream, it will introduce latency: events will be delayed until the next 'tick'.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Velocity Randomization
label: MIDI Rand Vel.
comment:
MIDI Velocity Randomization lets you randomize the velocity of MIDI notes (both note on and note off).

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Scale CC Value
label: MIDI CC Scale
comment:
MIDI Scale CC Value enables you to modify the value (data-byte) of a MIDI control change message.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Sostenuto
label: MIDI Sostenuto
comment:
MIDI Sostenuto delays note-off messages by a given time, emulating a piano sostenuto pedal. When the pedal is released, note-off messages that are queued will be sent immediately.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Velocity-Range Filter
label: MIDI Vel. Flt.
comment:
MIDI Velocity-Range Filter will filter MIDI note-on events according to velocity. Note-on events outside the allowed range are discarded. If a Note-off is received for a note that was previously filtered, it is also not passed though.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Velocity Adjust
label: MIDI Vel. Adjust
comment:
With MIDI Velocity Adjust, change the velocity of note events with separate controls for Note-on and Note-off. The input range 1 - 127 is mapped to the range between Min and Max. If Min is greater than Max, the range is reversed. The offsets value is added to the velocity event after mapping the Min/Max range.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Generator
label: MIDI Generator
comment:
A MIDI generator that plays fixed, predefined sequences. Select your key and play around with the BPM.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: Level Meter
label: Level Meter
comment:
The x42 Level Meter is a numeric audio signal level meter with a 15dB/sec falloff rate.
You can use it to analyse the level of an audio signal by keeping an eye on the RMS, Peak and Hold values.
Hold stores the highest Peak level that has been measured. There is a Reset control which resets the Hold value.
It is particularly useful for inspecting your signal chain at multiple points, to understand more about what signal levels work best for particular plugins.

name: Spectrum Analyzer
label: SpectrumAnalyzer
comment:
The x42 Spectrum Analyzer is a crude spectrum analyzer plugin with a configurable response time.
You can use it to analyse a signal's frequency contents.
It is particularly useful for inspecting your signal chain at multiple points, to understand more about the effect of certain plugins on the frequency contents.

name: MIDI Step Sequencer16x8
label: Step Seq. 16x8
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 16 notes and 8 steps.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Step Sequencer32x8
label: Step Seq. 32x8
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 32 notes and 8 steps.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Step Sequencer8x16
label: Step Seq. 8x16
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 16 notes and 8 steps.
Also available in 8x8 and 8x4 versions.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Step Sequencer8x4
label: Step Seq. 8x4
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 8 notes and 4 steps.
Also available in 8x8 and 8x4 versions.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: MIDI Step Sequencer8x8
label: Step Seq. 8x8
comment:
A simple step sequencer. It allows to trigger MIDI note events placed on a time/note grid.
The Step-duration is configurable to musical time and can optionally be modulated for a swing-time effect.
This plugin version contains 8 notes and 8 steps.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: TinyGain Mono
label: TinyGain Mono
comment:
A mono gain-stage with the range of +/-20dB and additional mute-control.
The gain control is low-pass filtered at 20Hz to prevent zipper noise.
The level display shows digital-peak (dBFS) of the output signal
(rise-time: immediate, falloff: 15dB/sec).
Also Available in a stereo version.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: TinyGain Stereo
label: TinyGain Stereo
comment:
A stereo gain-stage with the range of +/-20dB and additional mute-control.
The gain control is low-pass filtered at 20Hz to prevent zipper noise.
The level display shows digital-peak (dBFS) of the output signal
(rise-time: immediate, falloff: 15dB/sec).
Also Available in a mono version.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: Instrument Tuner
label: Tuna Tuner
comment: Musical instrument tuner with strobe characteristics

name: Stereo X-Fade
label: Stereo X-Fade
comment:
The Stereo X-Fade lets you crossfade two stereo tracks. Use the two controls to adjust the amount of each channel and shape your sound.

Features:
Modeled by x42

name: AMS Envelope
label: AMS Envelope
comment:
The AMS Env is a Control Voltage envelope module with added spice. It features extra parameters for hold and delay as well as a variable scale which scales the whole duration of the envelope.

Features:
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.

name: AMS LFO2 - Freq
label: AMS LFO2 - Freq
comment:
The AMS LFO2 module is a Control Voltage LFO which offers a variety of waveforms: sine, triangle, sawtooth up, sawtooth down, square and Sample & Hold. It also has an input that can be used to reset the phase of the LFO, and a control to set the phase-angle.

Features:
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.

name: AMS VCA Exp
label: AMS VCA Exp
comment:
The AMS VCA Exp module is an exponential Voltage Controlled Amplifier used for volume modulation. It allows you to, for instance, modulate the output of the AMS VCO3 using the control voltage signal of the AMS Env.

Features:
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.

name: AMS VCA Lin
label: AMS VCA Lin
comment:
The AMS VCA Lin module is a linear Voltage Controlled Amplifier used for volume modulation. It allows you to, for instance, modulate the output of the AMS VCO3 using the control voltage signal of the AMS Env.

Features: 
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.

name: AMS VCF
label: AMS VCF
comment:
The AMS VCF module is a voltage controlled filter which offers a wide variety of filter types and flavours (multiple low-pass and band-pass flavours, as well as a high-pass and notch option). Additionally, it enables you to use other CV signals to modulate some of its features, such as frequency and resonance. 

Features: 
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.

name: AMS VCO3
label: AMS VCO3
comment:
The AMS VCO3 is an oscillator module which can generate multiple waveforms (sine, square, triangle, sawtooth). Additionally, it features CV inputs that can be used for frequency and pulse-width modulation, as well as a Sync input which allows for various types of oscillator sync sounds. 

Features: 
Ported from the AlsaModularSynth, a free and open-source project.

name: Neural Amp Modeler
label: Neural Amp Modeler
comment:
The Neural Amp Modeler (NAM) is an open-source guitar software plugin that creates realistic simulations of analog gear, especially guitar amplifiers.
The plugin utilizes neural amp modeling technology, which employs neural networks and machine learning algorithms to replicate the behavior and characteristics of real amplifiers.

NAM loads *.nam files, enabling users to access a vast collection of meticulously crafted amp and pedal models.

You can discover a wide range of authentic tones, from vintage classics to modern designs at https://tonehunt.org/?tags=nano-mdl with their extensive library of nam models.
For MOD units search for the models with the #nano-mdl tag, as heavier models might not work.

NAM was created by Steven Ack and the LV2 version is maintained by Mike Oliphant.

name: GxQuack
label: GxQuack
comment: Envelope controlled wah pedal with some extra features

name: abGate
label: abGate
comment:
The abGate is a simple and straight-forward noise gate plugin. It helps to reduce noise and prevent feedback, this is especially useful when using overdrive or distortion effects.

Features:
Plugin by Antanas Bruzas

name: Invada Compressor (mono)
label: Compressor M
comment:
The Invada Compressor is a very easy to use, high-quality relaxed compressor that features 6 knobs and a high level of controllability. 

A compressor reduces the level of an audio signal if its amplitude exceeds the set threshold. The gain reduction is determined by the ratio: a ratio of 4:1 means that if the input level is 4dB over the threshold, the output signal is 1dB over the threshold. 

The ‘Attack’ controls how quickly the compressor starts to act. the ‘Release’ is the period when the compressor gradually stops acting. The Knee controls whether the bend in the response curve between below threshold and above threshold is abrupt (hard) or graduated (soft).  

Features:
Modeled by Invada

name: Invada Compressor (stereo)
label: Compressor St
comment:
The Invada Compressor is a very easy to use, high-quality relaxed compressor that features 6 knobs and a high level of controllability. 

A compressor reduces the level of an audio signal if its amplitude exceeds the set threshold. The gain reduction is determined by the ratio: a ratio of 4:1 means that if the input level is 4dB over the threshold, the output signal is 1dB over the threshold. 

The ‘Attack’ controls how quickly the compressor starts to act. the ‘Release’ is the period when the compressor gradually stops acting. The Knee controls whether the bend in the response curve between below threshold and above threshold is abrupt (hard) or graduated (soft).  

Features:
Modeled by Invada

name: Invada Delay Munge (mono in)
label: Delay Munge
comment:
The Delay Munge is a unique delay pedal that is great for ambient sounds. 
The Munge effect sets this pedal apart from the rest of the delay pedal family. It alters the shape and feel of each repetition caused by the delay effect. This can be controlled by changing the values of the LFO and Munge knobs and offers a lot of authenticity and dynamics to a sound.

Features:
Modeled by Invada

name: Invada Delay Munge (sum L+R in)
label: Delay Munge ST
comment:
The Delay Munge is a unique delay pedal that is great for ambient sounds. 
The Munge effect sets this pedal apart from the rest of the delay pedal family. It alters the shape and feel of each repetition caused by the delay effect. This can be controlled by changing the values of the LFO and Munge knobs and offers a lot of authenticity and dynamics to a sound.

Features:
Modeled by Invada

name: Invada Stereo Phaser (mono in)
label: SPhaser Mono
comment:
The Sphaser features unique controls such as Phase Offset and a very long oscillation which makes it a go-to pedal for authentic phase effects.

Features:
Modeled by Invada

name: Invada Stereo Phaser (stereo in)
label: SPhaser Stereo
comment:
This is the stereo version of the Sphaser effect.
The Sphaser features unique controls such as Phase Offset and a very long oscillation which makes it a go-to pedal for authentic phase effects.

Features:
Modeled by Invada

name: Invada Stereo Phaser (sum L+R in)
label: SPhaser Sum
comment:
This version of the Sphaser effect pedal sums up the two inputs.
The Sphaser features unique controls such as Phase Offset and a very long oscillation which makes it a go-to pedal for authentic phase effects.

Features:
Modeled by Invada

name: Black Pearl 4A
label: Black Pearl 4A
comment:
This plugin contains the 'Drumkits Percussion' section of the AVL Drumkits series.
These kits are intended to bring an authentic acoustic, organic drum sound to your arrangements and preserve real-world characteristics such as tom ringing and overtones,
unlike many General MIDI kits that sound sterile.
AVL Drumkits feature 5 sample layers per kit piece. The shell samples provide both center and edge hits to emulate right and left hands and the cymbals are quite realistic without truncated samples.

name: Black Pearl 4B
label: Black Pearl 4B
comment:
This plugin contains the 'Drumkits Percussion' section of the AVL Drumkits series.
These kits are intended to bring an authentic acoustic, organic drum sound to your arrangements and preserve real-world characteristics such as tom ringing and overtones,
unlike many General MIDI kits that sound sterile.
AVL Drumkits feature 5 sample layers per kit piece. The shell samples provide both center and edge hits to emulate right and left hands and the cymbals are quite realistic without truncated samples.

name: Black Pearl 5

comment:

AVL Drumkits feature 5 sample layers per kit piece. The shell samples provide both center and edge hits to emulate right and left hands.

Features:

name: Fluid Bass
label: Fluid Bass
comment:
Fluid Bass features 8 sample based bass sounds. It includes the classic bass sounds (slapping, picking etc.) as well as two synth based basses.
This generator features the bass section of the FluidGM SoundFont. 

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices
The FluidGM SoundFont was constructed from edited/cleaned/remixed samples found in the public domain and recordings made by Frank Wen.

name: Fluid Brass
label: Fluid Brass
comment:

name: Fluid Chromatic Percussion

name: Fluid Drums

comment:

This generator features the strings section of the FluidGM SoundFont.

This plugin contains the 'Synth Leads' section of the Fluid GM soundfont.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices.

name: Red Zeppelin 4
label: Red Zeppelin 4
comment:
This plugin contains the 'Drumkits Percussion' section of the AVL Drumkits series.
These kits are intended to bring an authentic acoustic, organic drum sound to your arrangements and preserve real-world characteristics such as tom ringing and overtones,
unlike many General MIDI kits that sound sterile.
AVL Drumkits feature 5 sample layers per kit piece. The shell samples provide both center and edge hits to emulate right and left hands and the cymbals are quite realistic without truncated samples.

name: Red Zeppelin 5
label: Red Zeppelin 5
comment:
This plugin contains the 'Drumkits Percussion' section of the AVL Drumkits series.
These kits are intended to bring an authentic acoustic, organic drum sound to your arrangements and preserve real-world characteristics such as tom ringing and overtones,
unlike many General MIDI kits that sound sterile.
AVL Drumkits feature 5 sample layers per kit piece. The shell samples provide both center and edge hits to emulate right and left hands and the cymbals are quite realistic without truncated samples.

name: Audio File
label: Audio File
comment:
This is a simple audio file player plugin.

Just upload some files in the MOD file manager section (either loops, recordings or tracks) and load up the plugin.
Transport is rolling as long as the plugin is enabled and a file is selected.
You can also sync to host transport, which will play in frame-perfect sync, useful if you need a few loops playing together.

Files are streamed from disk if longer than 30 seconds in length, otherwise loaded entirely on RAM.

This plugin supports mono, stereo and quad files.
For quad files use the "Quad Channels" parameter to select which 2 outputs to use.

A CV output port is available, used to report the current play status as a CV signal, 0 when paused and 10v when playing.

Even though this player plugin can loop files, it is not an audio looper.
Audio can loop back to the beginning if enabled, but it does not resample or pitch-shift to fit the host BPM.
The audio files are played back as-is, with resampling only done when needed to match the host sample rate.

name: MIDI File
label: MIDI File
comment:
This is a simple MIDI file player plugin.

Just upload some files in the MOD file manager section (specifically MIDI songs) and load up the plugin.
Transport is rolling as long as the plugin is enabled and a file is selected.
You can also sync to host transport, so the player follows host start/stop controls.
When repeat mode is enabled, the player will restart playback from the beginning after playing the last MIDI event on the file.

Note that MIDI time is converted to wall-clock time, not beats or ticks.
This means the file is played exactly as it was made (as if in "song mode").
This ignores host BPM, as the plugin is intended to play full MIDI songs and not MIDI clips.

name: C* AutoFilter
label: AutoFilter
comment:
A versatile selection of filters of varying character in band and lowpass configuration. The cutoff frequency can be modulated by both the input signal envelope and by a fractal oscillator. The default settings provide some sort of an automatic wah effect.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* Click - Metronome
label: Click
comment:
A sample-accurate metronome featuring a variety of click sounds, ranging from a wooden box struck with a mallet to a synthetic beep. All click sounds are synthesised once when the plugin is loaded and then played back from memory.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* PhaserII - Mono phaser modulated by a Lorenz fractal
label: PhaserII
comment:
The Phaser II is a modern take on this classic, well-loved effect.
Thanks to its two modulation options, you will be able to customize your sound using either a traditional sine-based periodicity or the smoothened fractal oscillation.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* Plate - Versatile plate reverb
label: Plate
comment:
One of the most breathtaking reverb sounds of them all, a plate of sheet metal hanging in a box. The Plate plugin is based around the sound of a plate reverb, with its signature “smooth” reverb tail, and was crafted especially for a soft attack and smooth ambiance.
The Plate reverb is useful for a wide variety of sounds. It tends to get along very nicely with other reverbs or even drum kits!
Available in a stereo version.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* PlateX2 - Stereo in/out Versatile plate reverb
label: PlateX2
comment:
One of the most breathtaking reverb sounds of them all, a plate of sheet metal hanging in a box. The Plate plugin is based around the sound of a plate reverb, with its signature “smooth” reverb tail, and was crafted especially for a soft attack and smooth ambiance.
The Plate reverb is useful for a wide variety of sounds. It tends to get along very nicely with other reverbs or even drum kits!
Also available in a mono version.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* Scape - Stereo delay + Filters
label: Scape
comment:
The Scape delay looks like a straightforward delay pedal but there is more than meets the eye.
The Eighth, Triplet and Sixteenth settings from the drop down menu create a dotted sounding rhythm. 
The delayed sounds can be re-tuned with the Tune knob in the settings session. Set it to your standard tuning of 440Hz and hear a normal rhythmical sounding delay. Or use it to achieve some interesting modulated sounds. Each note will be slightly different, further increasing the uniqueness of this effect.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* Spice
label: Spice
comment:
Spice is your friend when more bass or more treble presence is called for and generic equalization does not work without raising the signal or noise level.
This pedal is mostly used to refresh the signal that has been subjected to low-quality analog equipment. This pedal features individual control over the low and high frequencies. Both have 3 knobs, one for the desired frequency on which the pedal should operate, one for the overall compression and one for the output gain of the frequency range.

A stereo version is available as SpiceX2.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* SpiceX2
label: SpiceX2
comment:
Spice is useful when more bass or more treble presence is called for and generic equalization does not work without raising the signal or noise level. This pedal is mostly used to refresh the signal that has been subjected to low-quality analog equipment. This pedal features individual control over the low and high frequencies. Both have 3 knobs, one for the desired frequency on which the pedal should operate, one for the overall compression and one for the output gain of the frequency range.

A mono version is available as Spice.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* White - White noise generator
label: White
comment:
Mostly white pseudonoise, mixed and filtered from the output of two Dattorro multibit generators.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS

name: C* Wider - Stereo image Synthesis
label: Wider
comment:
Wider increases the width of a signal.
In addition to providing a basic panorama control, a perception of stereo width is created using complementary filters on the two outputs.

Features:
Modeled by CAPS
Based on the Orban 245F Stereo Synthesizer© (*)

(*) “Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
The Orban 245F Stereo Synthesizer© is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”

name: MDA BeatBox
label: BeatBox
comment:
Contains three samples (kick, snare and hat) designed to be triggered by incoming audio in three frequency ranges.  The default samples are based on the Roland CR-78.

To record your own sounds, use the Record control to monitor the plug's input, then with the source stopped select the slot to record into, play your sound, then with the source stopped again, switch back to monitoring.  This process is easier in an 'off line' editor such as WaveLab, rather than during a live mixdown in a DAW.

name: MDA DX10
label: DX10
comment:
The DX10 is inspired by the later Yamaha DX© (*) synthesizers which are some of the most popular digital synths in the world. This generator, however, was tweaked a bit to give it a warmer cleaner tone. It is 8-voice polyphonic and has a wide variety of sounds and presets. Some of these are bound to give you flashbacks to the 80’s where the DX series really shined!

Features:
Modeled by MDA
N.B. The carrier operator has a fixed coarse tuning ratio of 2.
(*) “Other product names modeled in the software trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD. Yamaha DX© is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of the product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”

name: MDA Detune
label: Detune
comment:
The Detune is a low-quality stereo pitch shifter. It can be used for the sort of detune effects found on multi-effects. It will create a widening effect but wont ‘swoosh’ like a chorus.
This effect was very popular in the 80’s with bands such as Boston and Judas Priest, but Ozzy Osbourne is also known for using detuning on his vocals.

Features:
Modeled by MDA

name: MDA ePiano
label: ePiano
comment:
The ePiano is based around 12 carefully sampled and mastered Rhodes© Piano (*) samples.
Rhodes© Pianos are electrical instruments that were designed in the 40’s but only became popular in the 70’s. Instead of using strings to produce sound, it uses tin metal tines which are then amplified through an electrical pickup.

The modulation parameter is used to set the modulation depth and the modulation mode. If the modulation control is set to a negative value the LFO will be modulating panning. If it's set to a positive value it will modulate the volume, resulting in a classic tremolo effect.

Features:
Modeled by MDA
(*) “Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
Rhodes© Pianos are a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and were used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.”

name: MDA JX10
label: JX10
comment:
The JX10 is a polyphonic synthesizer with high-quality output and lot of options to modulate the filter. This can be done with both the envelope and/or the LFO.
Due to all its controls, this synthesizer gives you flexibility to create a vast variety of sounds. Or just to find some kick-ass tones among the presets.

Features:
Modeled by MDA

name: MDA Piano
label: Piano
comment:
The MDA Piano generates a variety of piano sounds.
It was designed for a very low CPU usage. Tweak the sound to fit to your personal needs, or check out the presets. There is a bunch of cool stuff in there.

Features:
Modeled by MDA

name: MDA Shepard
label: Shepard
comment:
The MDA Shepard is a risset-tone generator.
Use it to generate an endlessly rising or falling tone and build tension like never before.
The Mode parameter has options for just hearing the tone, ring modulating the input with the tone, or mixing the input with the tone.

Features:
Modeled by MDA

name: MDA SubSynth
label: SubSynth
comment:
All the bass you could ever want!
With the MDA SubSynth you’ll produce/filter harmonics, flip phase, add a smooth sub-octave, use it as an octave divider and more.
Be aware that you may be adding low frequency content outside of the range of your monitor speakers. To avoid clipping, follow up with a limiter plug-in.

Features:
Modeled by MDA

name: MDA ThruZero
label: ThruZero
comment:
Tape flanger and ADT

This plug simulates tape-flanging, where two copies of a signal cancel out completely as the tapes pass each other.
It can also be used for other "modulated delay" effects such as phasing and simple chorusing.

name: MDA Vocoder
label: Vocoder
comment:
This 16-band vocoder applies the spectrum of your voice to the waveform of an instrument.
Plug your voice signal into the Modulator input and the instrument into the Carrier input.
The modulator and carrier inputs will be split into a series of frequency-bands that are modifiable with the vocoder.
After that, each carrier band will be modulated and added at the end. This vocoder also features an adjustable envelope and output level.

Features:
Modeled by MDA

name: BandPassFilter
label: BandPassFilter
comment:
A band pass filter, "Freq" determines its Center frequency, "Q" works on the filter bandwith and "Order" is the filter's order
(or how fast frequencies above the higher cutoff frequency and below the lower cutoff frequency will decay).
Higher the order, faster the decay.

name: Open Big Muff
label: Big Muff
comment:
The MOD Big Muff is inspired by the classic Electro-Harmonix Big Muff Pi(*).
This massive pedal has defined the sound of rock guitar!

Throughout the late 1960s and early 1970s the fuzz revolution took place spicing up rock and roll music. The Electro-Harmonix Big Muff Pi* was one of its greatest representatives. 

Its rich tone and creamy, violin-like sustain made its name among legends of all times and styles - from Hendrix and Pink Floyd, to Sonic Youth and the White Stripes.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices
Based on the classic Electro-Harmonix Big Muff Pi*

(*) 'Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
Electro-Harmonix Big Muff Pi is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.'

name: Capo
label: Capo
comment:
The Capo is a pitch-shifter that can raise the pitch with a maximum of +12 semitones (steps). It is more limited than the SuperCapo, but it also uses less processing power, allowing you to use the resources for other plugins!

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: CrossOver 2
label: CrossOver
comment:
The Two Way CrossOver is a simple and effective filter for splitting your signal in two different frequency ranges. 
It acts by applying a high pass filter and a low pass filter on each other outputs.
The Frequency knob defines on which frequency you want to start filtering the signal, while the Order switch indicates how intensively the cutoff frequency will decay. 

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: CrossOver 3
label: CrossOver3
comment: This plugin receives an input signal and outputs 3 filtered signals. First one is filtered with a low pass filter (LPF), the second with a band pass filter (BPF) and the third with a high pass filter (HPF), cutoff frequency used on LPF and as the lower frequency from BPF is controlled by "Freq 1" and cutoff frequency used as the higher frequency on BPF and in HPF is controlled by "Freq 2". "Order" indicates filter's orders (or how fast frequencies above (in HPF) or below (in LPF) the cutoff frequency will decay. Higher the order, faster the decay) ."Gain 1", "Gain 2" and "Gain 3" controls the gains of all outputs respectively.

name: DS1
label: DS1
comment:
The DS1 is modeled after the legendary BOSS DS-1(*), a distortion pedal mainly used for guitar.

Simply put, the DS1 distortion pedal is a modern classic. It was first produced in 1978 and is still widely popular. No wonder it was part of pedalboards from great names such as Kurt Cobain, Joe Satriani, Steve Vai and Josh Klinghoffer.

The DS1 features three knobs which can take the sound in a variety of different directions. By cranking up its tone levels and distortion knobs, you can pull out a range of different tones, from subtle bite to rich crunch to all-out fuzz. The midrange on the DS1 is scooped, giving it a distinct tonal flavor, which many players prefer. Want sonic reference? Give Nirvana's "Smells Like Teen Spirit" a listen - all that crunch came courtesy of a DS1.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices
Based on the classic BOSS DS-1(*)

(*) 'Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
BOSS DS-1 is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.'

name: Drop
label: Drop
comment:
Drop is a pitch-shifter that can drop the pitch to a maximum of -12 semitones (steps). Have more control over your processing power by adjusting the fidelity of the plugin. A lower fidelity means a less pristine sound, but less processing power and vice-versa.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Gain
label: Gain
comment:
Simple mono volume gain plugin without "zipping" noise when messing around with the gain parameter.
Also available in a stereo version.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Gain 2x2
label: Gain 2x2
comment:
A simple stereo volume gain plugin without "zipping" noise when messing around with the gain parameter.
Also available in a mono version. 

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Harmonizer
label: Harmonizer
comment:
The Harmonizer is a (relatively) simple harmonizer plugin that allows you to set the scale to either Major, Minor, or Minor Harmonic, and then shift up a +3rd or +6th, or down a -3rd or -6th in that scale. As with nearly all harmonizers, you will have to play in the correct key (which can also be configured).

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Harmonizer2
label: Harmonizer2
comment:
It’s a 2-voice harmonizer plugin that allows you to set the scale(*) to either Major, Minor, or Minor Harmonic, and then shift anywhere between down an -8th and up an +8th in that scale. Like with nearly all harmonizers, you will have to play in the correct key (which can also be configured). 

The “Mode” switch has three settings, in the first setting, it will mute the harmonized note when playing outside the scale. In the second setting, it will play the harmonized note, regardless of whether it is within the scale or not. In the third (“Bend”) setting, it behaves like the second setting, while also allowing you to bend notes, allowing for smooth transitions between harmonized notes. 

All plugins in the MOD-pitchshifter family have an option to set the fidelity of the plugin. As you lower the fidelity, the sound will become less pristine, but the plugin will also use less processing. The opposite holds true for increasing the fidelity, this will grant you a clearer pitch-shifted signal at the cost of significantly more processing being used. 

*The Lo-Fi setting is reminiscent of bit-crushed sounds, if you are looking for those synthesizer-like basslines, or dirty octave-up sounds, this is your setting!
*The Hi-Fi setting is great if you are looking to emulate (for example) something like a 12-string guitar, be sure to mind that CPU-meter in the bottom-right of the screen though! 
*The settings in between are created to let you make the perfect trade-off between quality and performance. 

A hint for making the right decision: the more you shift the pitch up, the higher you will need to set the Fidelity to get a clear sound. 

(*) The scale can be set by pressing the gear at the top-right corner of the plugin, in a future release, the interface will support doing this without entering the settings.

name: HighPassFilter
label: HighPassFilter
comment:
A simple high pass filter, "Freq" determines its cutoff frequency and "Order" the filter order, or how fast frequencies above the cutoff frequency will decay. Higher the order, faster the decay.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: LowPassFilter
label: Lowpass
comment:
A simple low pass filter, "Freq" determines its cutoff frequency and "Order" the filter order, or how fast frequencies above the cutoff frequency will decay. Higher the order, faster the decay.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: MIDI SwitchBox 1-2
label: MIDI SwitchBox 1-2
comment:
The SwitchBox 1-2 allows you to route the MIDI input to one of the two MIDI outputs of the plugin.

Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the target control.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Super Capo
label: Super Capo
comment:
It’s a pitch-shifter that can raise the pitch with a maximum of +24 semitones (steps). It has a bigger range than the Capo, but it also uses more processing power. If +12 semitones up are enough for you, consider using the regular Capo plugin.

All plugins in the MOD-pitchshifter family have an option to set the fidelity of the plugin. As you lower the fidelity, the sound will become less pristine, but the plugin will also use less processing. The opposite holds true for increasing the fidelity, this will grant you a clearer pitch-shifted signal at the cost of significantly more processing being used. 

*The Lo-Fi setting is reminiscent of bit-crushed sounds, if you are looking for those synthesizer-like basslines, or dirty octave-up sounds, this is your setting!
*The Hi-Fi setting is great if you are looking to emulate (for example) something like a 12-string guitar, be sure to mind that CPU-meter in the bottom-right of the screen though! 
*The settings in between are created to let you make the perfect trade-off between quality and performance. 

A hint for making the right decision: the more you shift the pitch up, the higher you will need to set the Fidelity to get a clear sound.

name: Super Whammy
label: Super Whammy
comment:
Inspired by the classic DigiTech Whammy© (*), this pitch-shifter can shift an input pitch from -12 semitones down to +24 semitones up. Originally launched in the early 90’s, the DigiTech Whammy© (*) aimed to emulate the sounds of a guitar bar vibrato with an enhanced pitch range.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices
(*) 'Other product names modeled in this software are trademarks of their respective companies that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD.
DigiTech Whammy© is a trademark or trade name of another manufacturer and was used merely to identify the product whose sound was reviewed in the creation of this product. All other trademarks are the property of their respective holders.

name: Switchbox 1-2
label: Switchbox 1-2
comment:
The SwitchBox 1-2 allows you to route a mono audio signal to one of the two mono outputs.
Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the channel control.

There is also a stereo version available of this plugin.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: ToggleSwitch
label: ToggleSwitch4
comment:
The ToggleSwitch enables the output depending on the button state.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Arpeggiator
label: Arpeggiator
comment:
The MOD Arpeggiator is a classic arpeggiator with some added spice. The plugin is specifically designed for the MOD platform, with a focus on live usage.

Besides the standard arpeggiator controls, there is also a special control, called "Octave Mode". When set to "1 Up / Cycle", the plugin acts as the typical arpeggiator we all know and love. The other options provide more variations to extend the classic paradigm.

The plugin has multiple sync modes. In "Free Running" mode, it will use the internal tempo of the plugin, which is set by the BPM parameter. In "Host Sync" mode, it will use the host tempo. When "Quantized Start" is selected, it will use the host-tempo, and make sure that all notes are quantized. This allows the plugin and the notes that it sends to be perfectly in sync with other plugins and devices.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Logic Operators
label: Logic Operators
comment:
The MOD CV Logic Operators is a CV plugin that can do all the common logic operations.
The included operators are; INV, NAND, AND, OR, NOR, XOR and XNOR. If the outcome is false the plugin outputs 0v, if true it outputs 10v.


The threshold value that is used to determine if an incoming signal is true or false can be adjusted with the switchpoint parameter.

Lastly, there is the hysteresis parameter. This parameter can be used to create a different  switchpoint for true and false. For example when the switchpoint parameter is set to 5v and the hysteresis parameter is set to 2v, the switch point for true will be at 6v and the switchpoint for false will be at 4v.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: MIDI SwitchBox 1-2 2C
label: MIDI SwitchBox 1-2 2C
comment:
The SwitchBox 1-2 2C allows you to route the dual MIDI input to one of the two dual MIDI outputs of the plugin.

Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the target control.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: MIDI SwitchBox 1-3
label: MIDI SwitchBox 1-3
comment:
The SwitchBox 1-3 allows you to route the MIDI input to one of the three MIDI outputs of the plugin.

Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the target control.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: MIDI SwitchBox 2-1
label: MIDI SwitchBox 2-1
comment:
The MIDI SwitchBox 2-1 allows you to route one of the two MIDI inputs to the single MIDI output of the plugin.

Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the source control.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: MIDI SwitchBox 2-1 2C
label: MIDI SwitchBox 2-1 2C
comment:
The SwitchBox 2-1 2C allows you to route one of the dual MIDI outputs to the dual MIDI output of the plugin.

Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the source control.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: MIDI SwitchBox 3-1
label: MIDI SwitchBox 3-1
comment:
The MIDI SwitchBox 3-1 allows you to route one of the three MIDI inputs to the single MIDI output of the plugin.

Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the source control.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: MIDI to CV mono
label: MIDI to CV mono
comment:
MIDI to CV mono converts a midi message to monophonic control voltage, 1/12 volt per note. It also features a retrigger knob, which retriggers the gate when it switches back to a previous voice that is still active. This is particularly useful when combined with short envelopes.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: MIDI to CV Poly
label: MIDI to CV Poly
comment:
MIDI to CV poly enables you to convert a midi message to polyphonic control voltages, 1/12 volt per note.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Mixer
label: Mixer
comment:
The MOD Mixer is an audio mixer with 4 mono channels. Each channel has a Volume, Pan, Mute and Alt parameter.

In addition to the main output pair there is also an alternative output pair. When the Alt parameter is enabled on a channel, that channel is no longer sent to the main outputs, but instead is sent to the alternative outputs.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Mixer Stereo
label: Mixer Stereo
comment:
The MOD Mixer Stereo is an audio mixer with 4 stereo channels. Each channel has a Volume, Pan, Mute and Alt parameter.

In addition to the main output pair there is also an alternative output pair. When the Alt parameter is enabled on a channel, that channel is no longer sent to the main outputs, but instead is sent to the alternative outputs.

When the True Panning parameter is enabled the Pan parameters won't work as a balance between the L en R channel but as a direction control (e.g., when the pan parameter is turned to the left both the L and R channel are on the left speaker).

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Audio to CV
label: Audio to CV
comment:
Audio to CV converts an audio signal to a control voltage signal.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Multi Button to CV
label: Multi Button CV
comment: A plugin that translates button actions to various CV signals

name: CV ABS
label: CV ABS
comment:
The MOD CV ABS performs a mathematical operation on the signal that is particularly useful for algorithmic and generative patches. The plugin converts the incoming CV value to an absolute value, which means that it returns the distance between the incoming value and zero. The result is that all negative input values will become positive on the output.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Attenuverter Booster
label: Attenuverter Booster
comment:
Attenuverter Booster multiplies the CV signal by any given value between -10 and +10.
The plugin can also be used to set an offset to the incomming signal.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV Clock
label: CV Clock
comment:
CV Clock generates CV clock pulses or square waves in multiple divisions. The clock can run in free mode or be signed with the host tempo.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Control to CV
label: Control to CV
comment:
Control to CV enables you to generate a control voltage signal from a control value.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV Gate
label: CV Gate
comment:
A variable CV gate that has a parameter to set the value that opens the gate and a parameter that sets the value that closes the gate.

The plugin sends the input signal to the output whenever the gate is opened. When the gate is closed, the output will send the value 0v.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV meter
label: CV meter
comment:
The CV Meter displays the value of the current incoming CV signal and the lowest and highest measured value over time.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV Parameter Modulation
label: CV Parameter Modulation
comment:
The MOD CV Parameter Modulation plugin is a control voltage utility specifically designed for use with MOD Devices’ products.
Its purpose is to facilitate mapping internal control voltage signals to plugin parameters, using the “manage CV ports” feature.

The PARAMETER VALUE sets the initial value (before modulation is applied) of the mapped plugin parameter.
The MODULATION DEPTH sets the amount of modulation on the mapped plugin parameter, coming from the control voltage input of the CV Parameter Modulation plugin. To invert the polarity of the modulation, set this parameter to a negative amount.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Random Generator
label: Random Generator
comment:
This plugin generates random CV values within a configurable range. A new random value can be generated by pressing the trigger button, or by sending a value greater than or equal to 1v to the CV input port.

The value on the CV input needs to drop down below 1v before a new value can be triggered again.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV Range Divider
label: CV Range Divider
comment:
The MOD CV Range Divider routes the incoming signal to one of its two outputs based on the configured range and the value of the incoming signal. If the signal is within the set range it goes to the first output, when the signal is out of range it’s routed to the second output.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV Round
label: CV Round
comment:
The MOD CV Round performs multiple mathematical operations that are useful for algorithmic and generative patches. Each operation has its own dedicated output. The operations are round, ceil, floor and fraction.

For example if the incoming signal would be 1.4v the plugin would return a rounded value of 1.0v, the ceiled value of 2.0v, the floored value of 1.0v and the fraction which would be 0.4v.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Slew Rate Limiter
label: Slew Rate Limiter
comment:
Plugin to limit the speed of the rise and fall times of a CV signal.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV Switchbox 1-2
label: CV Switchbox 1-2
comment:
CV Switchbox 1-2 routes one cv input to either one of the two outputs.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV Switchbox 2-1
label: CV Switchbox 2-1
comment:
CV Switchbox 2-1 routes either one of the two cv inputs to one cv output.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV Switchbox 1-3
label: CV Switchbox 1-3
comment:
CV Switchbox 1-3 routes one cv input to either one of the three outputs.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: CV Switchbox 3-1
label: CV Switchbox 3-1
comment:
CV Switchbox 3-1 routes either one of the three cv inputs to one cv output.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices

name: Switchbox 1-2 ST
label: Switchbox 1-2 ST
comment:
The SwitchBox 1-2 STEREO allows you to route a stereo signal to one of the two stereo outputs. Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the channel control.

There is also a mono version available of this plugin.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Switchbox 2-1
label: Switchbox 2-1
comment:
The SwitchBox 2-1 allows you to route one of the two inputs to a single output. Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the channel control.

There is also a stereo version available of this plugin.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: Switchbox 2-1 ST
label: Switchbox 2-1 ST
comment:
The SwitchBox 2-1 STEREO allows you to route one of the two stereo inputs to the stereo output.
Switch the routing on the fly by mapping the channel control.

There is also a mono version available of this plugin.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: SooperLooper
label: SooperLooper
comment:
The SooperLooper is a simple, straightforward looping station. Use it to layer some vocal or guitar harmonies.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: SooperLooper 2x2
label: SooperLooper 2x2
comment:
This is a stereo version of the SooperLooper.
A simple, straightforward looping station. Use it to layer some vocal or guitar harmonies.

Features:
Modeled by MOD Devices

name: TAP Chorus/Flanger
label: Chorus/Flanger
comment:
This plugin is an implementation capable of creating traditional Chorus and Flanger effects, spiced up a bit to make use of stereo processing.
It sounds best on guitar and synth tracks.

name: TAP Fractal Doubler
label: Fractal Doubler
comment:
Fractal Doubler is a vocal doubler which gives you full control over your doubling.
Choose your presets for great results or tweak the controls to find your sound signature.
It also produces interesting results with acoustic/electric guitars, bass and just about any other instrument.

Features:
Modeled by TAP

name: TAP Stereo Echo
label: Stereo Echo
comment:
Looking for a delay pedal with that will get any job done?

The Stereo Echo Tap is what you’re looking for. With basic controls such as delay time, feedback, dry and wet levels, you can create solid mono, stereo or even ping-pong like delay sounds.
Things will get interesting once you start playing with the Cross effect. Playing with this knob will give a wide, open and spacious effect, resulting in a more realistic sense of depth in your sound. For the audio-junkies out there, it’s the magic of the Haas effect. 

Features:
Modeled by TAP

name: TAP Pink/Fractal Noise
label: Pink Noise
comment:
This plugin came to life as a secondary product of the development of TAP Fractal Doubler. It adds pink noise to the incoming signal using a one-dimensional random fractal line generated by the Midpoint Displacement Method, which is a computationally cheap method suitable for generating random fractals.

source: http://tap-plugins.sourceforge.net/ladspa/pinknoise.html

name: TAP Reflector
label: Reflector
comment:
The Reflector creates a psychedelic effect.
It achieves this effect by reversing parts of the audio signal and leaving the rest unaffected. Set the Length knob to minimum to achieve a subtle effect or to maximum and enjoy the 60’s psychedelic feel. The dry and wet controls let you control the intensity of the effect and find the sweet spot for your sound.

Features:
Modeled by TAP

name: TAP Tremolo
label: Tremolo
comment:
The Tremolo effect is one of the oldest effects for guitar. It was created around the 1940s when the effect was added to tube amplifiers. This is a great straightforward tremolo with easy controls, suitable for use with any instrument. 

Features:
Modeled by TAP

name: TAP Tubewarmth
label: Tubewarmth
comment:
TubeWarmth adds the character of vacuum tube amplification to your audio tracks by emulating the sonically desirable nonlinear characteristics of triodes. In addition, this plugin also supports emulating analog tape saturation.

Features:
Modeled by TAP

name: Notes
label: Notes
comment:
Notes is a plugin to store arbitrary notes.

A few notes about Notes:
- For entering newlines, use Shift+Enter
- Font-height is configurable in the plugin settings
- There is a limit on how much you can write (around 450 characters at the moment)

Features:
Modeled by Open Music Kontrollers

name: avocado
label: avocado
comment:
Avocado is an easy to use, ingenious stutter/glitch effect. It works well on any instrument, but the effect is more noticeable when the input signal has snappy attacks, and sudden silences.
You can think of the Avocado as multiple delays running in parallel, where the signal randomly gets fed to one of the delay inputs, and is randomly played back from one of the delay outputs.

Avocado sports a single control: TIME. Change the value to change the duration of the effect. For more predictable glitching it is recommended to sync the TIME parameter to a musical subdivision of the tempo, especially for rhythmic parts.

Features:
Plugin by remaincalm

name: floaty
label: floaty
comment:
Floaty is a wild modulation/delay effect that is reminiscent of a tape delay. One of the key features is the variable playback speed, allowing for repeats that ascend/descend in pitch.

There are six controls available to tame the beast: three common delay parameters (TIME, MIX and FEEDBACK) and three more special ones. WARP sets the amount of modulation with the left side being mellow and the right side being fast. TONE sets a combination of bandpass filter frequency and resonance. RATE sets the playback speed anywhere between -200% and +200%.
Disclaimer: the delay buffer is cleared whenever the TIME parameter gets a new value.

Features:
Plugin by remaincalm

name: mud
label: mud
comment:
Mud is a dark and dirty modulation/filter effect. It is particularly useful to fans of grittier, more lo-fi sounds, but it is capable of interesting univibe-style modulation too.

MIX blends between the dry and processed signal, FILTER sets a combination of bandpass filter frequency and resonance and LFO sets a combination of speed and depth for the effect, with the left side being deep and the right side being mellow.

Features:
Plugin by remaincalm

name: paranoia
label: paranoia
comment:
Paranoia is a digital distortion/mangler effect. It works particularly well for gnarly destructive fuzz sounds or for adding glassy aliasing to your sound.

The LEVEL parameter sets the post-saturation gain. FILTER sweeps between bandpass, highpass and bypass. The CRUSH parameter sweeps between bit depths and sampling rates. MANGLE sweeps through bit-flip/mute patterns, and is interactive with CRUSH.

For those interested in the inner workings:
The FILTER parameter functions as a band pass filter between 0 and 80, as a high pass filter between 80 and 99 and when set to 100 the filter is completely bypassed. 
CRUSH goes from 300Hz-30kHz 6 bit on the left side, to 300Hz-30kHz 10 bit on the right side, with 48kHz 10 bit on the far right position.

Features:
Plugin by remaincalm

name: Filta
label: Filta
comment:
A highpass and lowpass filter combined in a single knob!
The simplest way of limiting your frequency range or sweeping your sound around.

Features:
Modeled by OpenAV

name: Kuiza
label: Kuiza
comment:
OpenAV Kuiza is a four-band EQ with low, low-mid, hi-mid, high and an overall gain control.

Features:
Modeled by openAV

name: Roomy
label: Roomy
comment:
Our most easy to use reverb is the roomy reverb. It doesn't get more straightforward than this!
With 3 simple controls, it takes just a blink to get the roomy pedal to sound good. The Decay knob allows you to set the duration of the reverb, the Damping knob allows you to control the high frequencies in the reverb tail, producing a warmer sound with less “edge”, and finally the Mix knob selects the amount of dry and wet signal. 
Room reverbs add a natural color and liveliness to the sound. When you’re going for a natural, in-person kind of sound (a pretty common goal in acoustic styles of music), the roomy reverb is a good choice. 

Features:
Modeled by OpenAV

name: Bollie Delay
label: Bollie Delay
comment:
The Bollie Delay is a stereo tempo delay featuring high pass and low pass filter as well as a host tempo function, granting more control over your delay settings. This powerful delay is perfect for experimenting with your vocals or your guitar. 

Features:
Modeled by Bollie

name: AudioToCV Pitch
label: AudioToCV Pitch
comment:
The Audio To CV Pitch plugin is a tool that turns your audio signal into CV pitch and CV gate signals.
This allows audio from instruments (such as guitars) to play and control synth sounds and effects.

It detects the pitch in your incoming audio signal and outputs a 1V/Oct CV pitch signal on the top output.
The bottom output carries the CV gate signal, it sends out 10V while a pitch is detected, and resets to 0V when the pitch can no longer be detected.

The Sensitivity parameter can be increased to detect quieter signals, or decreased to reduce artifacts.
The Octave parameter allows you to shift the detected pitch up or down by a maximum of 4 octaves. When set to 0, it will output the same pitch as is detected on the input.

The plugin also features 3 parameters that are not visible on the plugin interface:
 - The Hold Pitch parameter sets whether the plugin resets its outputs to 0, or holds the last detected pitch.
 - Increase the Confidence Threshold to make sure the correct pitch is being output, or decrease it to get a faster response time.
 - The Tolerance parameter influences how quickly you can change pitch, turn it down for a more accurate pitch output, or turn it up to make it easier to jump from one pitch to the next.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Devices & DISTRHO
Initial work by Bram Giesen

name: Schrammel OJD
label: OJD
comment:
The Schrammel OJD is heavily inspired by the schematics of a modern classic analog pedal.

For best sounding results put this somewhere before your guitar amp (plugin) and before reverb, delay and modulation plugins, just as you would place a real pedal on your pedal board.
Being creative and using it somewhere else in your chain is possible too but be prepared that this may cause a lot of sharp high frequencies.

There are two basic sound characteristics you can select with the upper mid slide switch.
The LP mode gives you a warmer tone with slightly less gain, the HP mode boost some higher frequencies, leading to a more aggressive distortion with some more gain.

Features:
Modeled by Janos Buttgereit

name: Record-Mono Mini
label: Record-Mono Mini
comment:
Mono Recorder plugin with a minimalistic UI, save audio stream as wav or ogg files.

Features:
Developed by Brummer

name: Record-Quad Mini
label: Record-Quad Mini
comment:
Quad Reocrder plugin with a minimalistic UI, save audio stream as 4 channel wav or ogg files.

Features:
Developed by Brummer

name: Record-Stereo Mini
label: Record-Stereo Mini
comment:
Stereo Reocrder plugin with a minimalistic UI, save audio stream as wav or ogg files.

Features:
Developed by Brummer

name: ChowCentaur
label: ChowCentaur
comment:
Chow Centaur is a digital emulation of the Klon Centaur guitar pedal (*)

The plugin contains two modes:
- "Traditional" uses traditional circuit modelling techniques
- "Neural" uses a recurrent neural network to model the gain stage from the original circuit

Features:
Modeled by Jatin Chowdhury

(*) 'Product names and trademarks are the property of their respective holders that do not endorse and are not associated or affiliated with MOD Audio or Klon Centaur; they were used merely to identify the product whose sound was incorporated in the creation of this plugin.'

name: Dragonfly Hall Reverb
label: Hall Reverb
comment:
Dragonfly Hall Reverb is a high fidelity reverb effect.
It is primarily intended for use as a concert hall reverb.
It also has numerous smaller presets representing rooms, studios, and chambers. 

Please note that the Dry Level, Early Level, Early Send and Late Level controls are decoupled from the preset.
This allows you to set the levels and explore the different presets without the levels changing.

The plugin has basic controls to set the Size, Width, Predelay and Decay.
There are also more advanced controls to further tweak the reverb: Diffuse, Modulation, Spin and Wander.
Finally, there are two filter sections (High and Low) with Cut, Cross and Mult controls.

Features:
Plugin by Michael Willis
Based on Hibiki Reverb from Freeverb3 VST
GUI by FistfulOfStars

name: Harmless
label: Harmless
comment:
Harmless is a waveshapeable harmonic tremolo with a stereo phase control.

Features:
Modeled by SHIRO

name: Larynx
label: Larynx
comment:
The Larynx is a simple, great sounding vibrato effect with a tone control. The Depth knob controls the intensity of the modulation effect and Rate changes the modulation frequency.

Features:
Modeled by SHIRO

name: Modulay
label: Modulay
comment:
The Modulay is a delay with various types of modulation. Experiment by playing around with the Morph knob to get unprecedented results.

Features:
Modeled by Shiro

name: Shiroverb
label: Shiroverb
comment:
This shimmery reverb is based on the "Gigaverb"-genpatch and the "Pitch-Shift"-genpatch from Max MSP. 

Features:
Modeled by Shiro

name: Wolf Shaper
label: Wolf Shaper
comment: Waveshaping distortion plugin with spline-based graph.

name: Cabinet Loader
label: Cabinet Loader
comment:
The MOD Cabinet Loader enables you to play through your favorite cabinet impulse responses (IRs).

The plugin is very easy to use: Simply select the IR file, set the level as desired and off you go.

IRs can be uploaded using the file manager in either WAV and FLAC format.
Multi-channel files are supported but always processed in mono mode using the first channel.
For faster loading it is recommended to use WAV format files with 48kHz and 24 bit.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Audio & DISTRHO, based on HiFi-LoFi FFTConvolver engine.

name: Convolution Loader
label: Convolution Loader
comment:
The MOD Convolution Loader enables you to easily create custom reverb and other effects using impulse responses (IRs).

Using a very resource effective processing, it allows IRs with a length of up to 15s on the MOD Dwarf and MOD Duo X, less on the MOD Duo.

IRs can be uploaded using the file manager in either WAV and FLAC format.
Multi-channel files are supported but always processed in stereo mode.
For faster loading it is recommended to use WAV format files with 48kHz and 24 bit.

The plugin is very easy to use: Simply select the IR file, set the levels as desired, optionally filter out some low end with the built-in high pass filter, and off you go.

There is a Trails switch in the advanced settings;
when enabled the reverb tail peacefully decays when you bypass the plugin, disable it and the tail will immediately disappear when bypassed.

Features:
Plugin by MOD Audio & DISTRHO, based on HiFi-LoFi FFTConvolver engine.

name: Neural Record
label: Neural Record
comment:
Neural Record, a plug to make the process of cloning external soft/hardware a bit more comfortable. 

It features a round trip measurement routine. 
This allows to load the plug, connect the output to the system output, 
loop over external gear (soft or hardware) back over the System Input to the Neural Record input.

Simply press "Capture" to play the "input.wav" file to the output and record the returning input 
delayed by the measured round trip latency. 

Resulting recorded "target.wav" file will be perfectly in sync with the used "input.wav" file. 
Currently, both files would be saved under "/data/user-files/Audio Recordings/profiles/". 
The "target.wav" file will be overwritten on each capture run, so there will be always only one target file.
You need to download it from the device in order to use it with the AIDA-X or the NAM trainer.

The round-trip latency will be measured on each "Capture" start. 

The "input.wav" file comes as resource with the plug and get copied over to 
"/data/user-files/Audio Recordings/profiles/", when no input.wav file was found there. 
This allows advanced users to use their own input.wav file by simply replace the one in that folder. 

The target.wav file get checked during record and run to a normalisation function when needed. 
(Only when the max peek in target is above the max peek in input). 

The record will be saved in the PCM24 wav format (same as the input.wav file).

The UI provide a progress bar, a peek-meter and, well the capture button.

Features:
Developed by Brummer

name: DIE Fluid Synth
label: DIE Fluid Synth
comment:
The DIE Fluid Synth is a generator plugin that makes use of SF2 Instrument files (with support for the unofficial vorbis/flac-encoded SF3 format).
Upload your own instruments to your MOD Device through the file manager, and use this plugin to play them by sending MIDI notes to its input.
The entire file is loaded into RAM.

Some SF2 Instrument files contain multiple patches, and some are even multi-timbral, using a MIDI channel per timbre.
MIDI program changes can be used to change the instrument patch for the respective MIDI channel.

The plugin can tweak the chorus and reverb defined in the SF2 instrument.
The chorus is capable of a wide range of sounds, from thickening the sound to all-out wacky modulation, while the reverb helps giving that finishing touch to the sound.

Features:
Original plugin from Ardour Community Effects, based on Fluid Synth engine
Adapted & maintained by DISTRHO
GUI by MOD Devices

name: Dragonfly Early Reflections
label: Early Reflections
comment:
Dragonfly Early Reflections is a reverb effect based on Moorer's early reflection model.
This is the same algorithm used in Dragonfly Hall and Dragonfly Room, but without any late reverberation algorithm.

There are eight Reflection types to pick from; The names are primarily meant to be memorable, and are only vaguely related to how each reflection type sounds.

The plugin has controls to set the Wet Level, Dry Level, Size and Width. It also comes with post-reverb Low cut and High cut parameters.

Features:
Plugin by Michael Willis
Based on Freeverb3 VST
GUI by FistfulOfStars

name: Dragonfly Plate Reverb
label: Plate Reverb
comment:
Dragonfly Plate is an easy to use, high fidelity plate reverb plugin.

It comes with a variety of plate and tank presets for you to explore.
Please note that Wet level and Dry level controls are decoupled from the preset.
This allows you to set the levels and explore the different presets without the levels changing.

There are three different Reverb types available:
- Simple, a thin plate algorithm with a sparse tail and some slight early reflections
- Nested, a thick plate algorithm with a dense tail and no early reflections
- Tank, a tank algorithm based on Jon Dattorro's Effect Design paper

The plugin has controls to set the Width, Predelay and Decay.
It also comes with pre-reverb Low cut and High cut parameters, and a Dampen control which controls a low pass filter applied to the reverb algorithm's internal feedback loop.

Features:
Plugin by Michael Willis
Based on Nverb and STRev from Freeverb3 VST
GUI by FistfulOfStars

name: Dragonfly Room Reverb
label: Room Reverb
comment:
Dragonfly Room Reverb is a high fidelity reverb effect.
It has several different room presets, as well as a small number of hall presets and effect presets.

Please note that the Dry Level, Early Level, Early Send and Late Level controls are decoupled from the preset.
This allows you to set the levels and explore the different presets without the levels changing.

The plugin has basic controls to set the Size, Width, Predelay and Decay.
There are also more advanced controls to further tweak the reverb: Diffuse, Spin and Wander.
Finally, there are two filter sections with controls for: High Cut, Early Damp, Late Damp, Low Cut, Low Boost and Boost Freq.

Features:
Plugin by Michael Willis
Based on ProG Reverb from Freeverb3VST
GUI by FistfulOfStars

name: ZamComp
label: ZamComp
comment:
This mono compressor strip will make your kick or your snare sound out of this world! 
Play around with the settings and find out how you can give life and punch to your sound.

Features:
Modeled by Zamaudio

name: ZamCompX2
label: ZamCompX2
comment:
This stereo compressor strip will make your kick or your snare sound out of this world! 
Play around with the settings and find out how you can give life and punch to your sound.

Features:
Modeled by Zamaudio
